EXECUTIVE SUMMARY

ACCIDENTAL RELEASE PREVENTION AND RESPONSE POLICIES

voestalpine Texas is highly committed to safety. This commitment is demonstrated by the resources invested in accident prevention, such as training personnel and incorporating safety into the design, installation, operation, and maintenance of the voestalpine Texas processes. The voestalpine Texas policy is to implement reasonable controls to prevent foreseeable releases of regulated substances. However, if a release does occur, facility personnel have been trained on how to respond to, control, and contain the release.



DESCRIPTION OF THE STATIONARY SOURCE AND REGULATED SUBSTANCES

The voestalpine Texas facility, located in Portland, Texas, operates eight processes covered by

the Environmental Protection Agency's (EPA's) risk management program (RMP) regulation and

Occupational Safety and Health Administration's (OSHA's) process safety management (PSM) standard. The covered processes, delineated in the most recent Process Hazard Analysis (PHA), include the following: Natural Gas Station, Reformer Process Gas Loop/Cooling System (Burners excluded), Flue Gas System, Combustion System, Reduction Furnace and Top Gas System, Process Gas Compressors, Seal Gas System, an Utility Systems. The regulated flammable substances involved in the voestalpine Texas facility's covered processes include hydrogen, methane, and a flammable natural gas mixture. 



GENERAL ACCIDENTAL RELEASE PREVENTION PROGRAM

The following is an executive summary of the accidental release prevention program in place at the voestalpine Texas facility. This summary includes a brief description of the accidental release prevention program and the management systems associated with it. 



Employee Participation

voestalpine Texas encourages employees to participate in all facets of process safety management and accident prevention. Examples of employee participation range from updating and compiling technical documents and chemic

al information to participating as a member of a process hazard analysis (PHA) team. Employees are given access to all information created as part of the accident prevention program that applies to the process in which they work via the voestalpine network server. The specific ways that employees can be involved in the accident prevention program is documented in the facility's Employee Participation procedure (PSM-002).



Process Safety Information

voestalpine Texas maintains a variety of technical documents that are used to help ensure the safe operation of its covered processes. These documents address chemical properties and associated hazards, limits for key process parameters, specific chemical inventories, and equipment design basis/configuration information. Chemical-specific information, including toxicity information, permissible exposure limits, physical data, reactivity data, corrosivity data, thermal and chemical stability data, and hazardous effects of inadvertent mixing of different materials that could foreseeable occur are provided in the safety data sheets (SDSs) available on the voestalpine network server. voestalpine Texas also maintains numerous technical documents that pertain to the equipment used in the process, including: materials of construction documents, piping and instrumentation diagrams (P&IDs), electrical classifications, ventilation system information, relief system designs and design basis, design codes employed, material and energy balances and safety systems, including interlocks and detection and suppression systems. This information, in combination with written procedures and trained personnel, provides a basis for establishing inspection and maintenance activities, as well as for evaluating proposed process and facility changes to ensure that the facility's safety features are not compromised.



Process Hazard Analysis (PHA)

voestalpine Texas has a comprehensive program to help ensure that hazards associated with its cover

ed processes are identified and controlled. Within this program, each process is systematically examined to identify hazards and ensure that adequate controls are in place to manage these hazards.

voestalpine Texas has used the HAZOP method for its most recent analysis.  HAZOP analysis, when performed by trained and knowledgeable personnel, is recognized by the Center for Chemical Process Safety (CCPS) as an acceptable hazard evaluation technique. Each analysis is conducted using a team of people who have operating and maintenance experience as well as engineering expertise. Each team identifies and evaluates the hazards of the process and accident prevention and mitigation measures. Each team then makes suggestions for additional prevention and/or mitigation measures whenever the team believes such measures are necessary.  Each PHA team's findings are forwarded to local management for resolution. Implementation of mitigation options in response to PHA findings is based on a relative risk ranking assigned by the PHA team. This ranking helps ensure that potential accident scenarios assigned the highest risk receive immediate attention. All approved mitigation options in response to PHA team findings are tracked until completion. The final resolution of each finding is documented and retained.

To help ensure process controls and/or process hazards do not deviate significantly from their original design features, voestalpine Texas periodically updates and revalidates the hazard analysis results for each of its covered processes. These periodic reviews are conducted at least every 5 years and will be conducted at this frequency for each process until a process is no longer operational. 

Once again, the team findings are forwarded to management for consideration, and the final resolution of each finding is documented and retained.

Operating Procedures

voestalpine Texas will maintain operating procedures for each of its covered processes that address various modes of

operations, such as (1) initial startup, (2) normal operations, (3) temporary operations, (4) emergency shutdowns, (5) emergency operations, (5) normal shutdown, and (6) startups following a turnaround or emergency shutdown.  These procedures are used as a reference by experienced operators and the basis for consistent training of new operators. These procedures will be periodically reviewed for completeness and accuracy. The procedures are kept current and accurate by revising them as necessary to reflect changes made through the management of change process.



Training

To complement the written procedures developed for each process, voestalpine Texas has implemented a comprehensive training program for all employees involved in operating a process. New employees receive training on their process' basic operations, if they are not already familiar with such operations.  The Head of SSE and/or the Safety Coordinator will confirm that personnel understand the initial and/or refresher training required by this procedure.  Verification is determined through written exams, hands-on training, field evaluations, and/or on-the-job training.  In the event that a voestalpine or contractor employee does not pass the verification process they will be prohibited from operating that process until a passing grade is achieved.  An Individual Training Record will be used to document personal training and the means used to verify that the training was understood. Refresher training will be conducted for all affected personnel at least every three years, during which training participants will be consulted about the appropriate frequency of the training.  



Contractors

voestalpine Texas uses contractors to supplement its workforce.  Due to the fact that some contractors work on or near covered process equipment, voestalpine Texas has put procedures in place to ensure that contractors: (1) perform their work in a safe manner, (2) have appropriate knowledge and skills, (3) are aw

are of the hazards in their workplace, (4) understand what to do in the event of an emergency, (5) understand and follow site safety rules, (6) inform appropriate personnel of any hazards they find, and (7) are selected appropriately, and (8) audited for safety frequently.  Any visitors (including vendors and consultants) on site for more than three days must undergo site orientation. Temporary basis badge owners must be escorted anywhere by anyone with an authorized long-term badge.  The Safety Coordinator will provide visitors with information regarding the known PSM hazards. 

Pre-startup Safety Reviews (PSSRs)

voestalpine Texas conducts a PSSR for any new facility or facility modification that requires a change in process safety information. The purpose of the PSSR is to ensure that safety features, procedures, personnel, and equipment are appropriately prepared for startup prior to placing the equipment into service. This review verifies construction is in accordance with design specifications and all supporting systems are operationally ready. During each PSSR, personnel use checklists to verify all aspects of readiness and verify all accident prevention program requirements have been properly implemented.



Mechanical Integrity

voestalpine Texas has established practices and procedures related to the equipment used in its covered processes. The basic aspects of the facility's mechanical integrity program include: (1) conducting training, (2) written procedures, (3) performing inspections and tests, (4) correcting identified deficiencies, and (5) safe work practices.  Training will be provided to each maintenance and contract employee involved in maintaining the on-going integrity of process equipment. Training will include an overview of the process (provided by safety department), a site safety orientation (provided by The Coastal Bend Contractor Safety Council), and HAZCOM (provided by safety department) training to assure that all personnel are aware of

the potential hazards of the facility's covered processes. Additionally, all personnel will be trained in procedures that are required for the performance of their specific job tasks to assure each task is performed in a safe and efficient manner. Training occurs through equipment suppliers, vendors on site, outside training entities, qualified voestalpine personnel, and on the job training. This includes classroom training, hands-on activities, written tests, and/or online training. Specific safety training can be conducted by the safety department.  Documentation of the trainings is stored on the voestalpine network server.  Inspections and tests, managed through SAP, are performed to help ensure that equipment functions as intended and to verify that equipment is within acceptable limits.  



Safe Work Practices

In addition to the specific maintenance procedures prepared, voestalpine Texas has written safe work practices such as its hot work procedure that applies to its flammable systems. The plant's Safety Coordinator maintains the written procedures for VSP-001, VSP-006, VSP-008, and VSP-010 on the voestalpine network server.

Management of Change

voestalpine Texas has developed a comprehensive system to manage changes to its covered processes.  This system requires that changes to items such as process equipment, chemicals, technology (including process operating conditions), procedures, and other facility changes be properly reviewed and authorized before being implemented. Changes are reviewed to (1) ensure that adequate controls are in place to manage any new hazards and (2) verify that existing controls have not been compromised by the change. Affected chemical hazard information, process operating limits, and equipment information, as well as procedures, are updated to incorporate these changes. In addition, operating and maintenance personnel receive training on relevant changes, when necessary.



Incident Investigation

voestalpine Texas promptly

investigates all incidents that resulted in, or reasonably could have resulted in, a fire/explosion, major property damage, environmental loss, or personal injury. The goal of each investigation is to determine the facts and develop corrective actions to prevent a recurrence of the incident or a similar incident.  voestalpine Texas employs the 5-Why method and other basic investigative techniques.  The investigation team documents its findings, develops recommendations to prevent a recurrence, and forwards these results to the management personnel for resolution. Corrective actions taken in response to the investigation team's findings and recommendations are tracked to completion. The final resolution of each finding / recommendation is documented and investigation results are reviewed with all affected employees (including contractors). Incident investigation reports are retained for at least 5 years so that reports can be reviewed during future PHAs and PHA revalidations.



FIVE-YEAR ACCIDENT HISTORY

The voestalpine Texas facility has not yet become operational. As such, the facility has no accident/release history to report.



EMERGENCY RESPONSE PROGRAM INFORMATION

voestalpine Texas maintains a written emergency response program, which is in place to protect its workers' and the public's safety, as well as the environment.  The program consists of procedures for responding to a release of a regulated substance, including the possibility of a fire or explosion if a flammable substance is accidentally released and ignited. The procedures address all aspects of emergency response, including proper first aid and medical treatment for exposures, evacuation plans, accounting for personnel after an evacuation, notification of local emergency response agencies and the public if a release occurs, and post-incident cleanup and decontamination requirements. In addition, the facility also developed procedures that address the maintenance, inspection, testing, and use of

emergency response equipment.  Employees receive training in these procedures as necessary to perform their specific emergency response duties.  The overall emergency response program for voestalpine Texas is coordinated with local emergency response officials, local government officials, and industry representatives. voestalpine Texas has around-the-clock communications capability with appropriate LEPC officials and emergency response organizations (e.g., fire department). This provides a means of notifying the public of an incident, if necessary, as well as facilitating quick response to an incident.



PLANNED CHANGES TO IMPROVE SAFETY

voestalpine Texas resolves all findings from PHAs, some of which result in modifications to the process.
